member.name: WS_SECURITY_PROPERTY_ID
member.summary: Identifies the properties representing channel-wide security settings. This enumeration is used within the structure, which is in turn used within a structure.

member.name: WS_SECURITY_PROPERTY_ID.WS_SECURITY_PROPERTY_TRANSPORT_PROTECTION_LEVEL
member.summary: A value that determines whether signing alone or signing plus encryption should be done for the connection. With at least one transport security binding in the security description, the default is WS_PROTECTION_LEVEL_SIGN_AND_ENCRYPT.

summary.para:
With mixed-mode security, this property is a structure that specifies the algorithm suite to be used. .
This property may not be used in conjunction with .
If neither this property nor is specified, the algorithm suite defaults to WS_SECURITY_ALGORITHM_SUITE_NAME_BASIC128 when is used andWS_SECURITY_ALGORITHM_SUITE_NAME_BASIC256 otherwise.

With mixed-mode security, this property is a structure that specifies the algorithm suite to be used. The suite names refer to collections of algorithms defined in WS-SecurityPolicy 1.1section 7.1.
This property may not be used in conjunction with .
If neither this property nor is specified, the algorithm suite defaults to when is used andWS_SECURITY_ALGORITHM_SUITE_NAME_BASIC256 otherwise.

member.name: WS_SECURITY_PROPERTY_ID.WS_SECURITY_PROPERTY_MAX_ALLOWED_LATENCY
member.summary: With mixed-mode security, this property is a WS_TIMESPAN structure that specifies the maximum allowed staleness of an incoming timestamp in the security header. The default is 5 minutes.

member.name: WS_SECURITY_PROPERTY_ID.WS_SECURITY_PROPERTY_TIMESTAMP_VALIDITY_DURATION
member.summary: With mixed-mode security, this property is a WS_TIMESPAN structure that specifies the timestamp generated by the sender will remain valid for this duration from the security application instant. This setting is sometimes called 'time-to-live' or 'TTL'. The default is 5 minutes.

member.name: WS_SECURITY_PROPERTY_ID.WS_SECURITY_PROPERTY_MAX_ALLOWED_CLOCK_SKEW
member.summary:
With mixed-mode security, this property is a WS_TIMESPAN structure that specifies the maximum skew allowed between the clocks of the sender and receiver. This quantity serves as a margin of tolerance on the enforcement of settings such as .
The default is 5 minutes.

member.name: WS_SECURITY_PROPERTY_ID.WS_SECURITY_PROPERTY_TIMESTAMP_USAGE
member.summary: With mixed-mode security, this property is a value that specifies whether a timestamp should be generated (at sender) and demanded (at receiver) in the security header. The default is WS_SECURITY_TIMESTAMP_USAGE_ALWAYS.

member.name: WS_SECURITY_PROPERTY_ID.WS_SECURITY_PROPERTY_SECURITY_HEADER_LAYOUT
member.summary: With mixed-mode security, this property is a value that specifies the layout of the security header. The default is WS_SECURITY_HEADER_LAYOUT_STRICT.

member.name: WS_SECURITY_PROPERTY_ID.WS_SECURITY_PROPERTY_SECURITY_HEADER_VERSION
member.summary: With mixed-mode security, this property is a value that specifies the WS-Security version to use for the security header. The default is WS_SECURITY_HEADER_VERSION_1_1.

summary.para: A value that specfies whether to validate Extended Protection data. Only available if extended protection is used.
The default is on configurations that support extended protection.
This property is only available on the server and can only be used when with either or is used.

Supported by default on Windows 7 and above. May require an update on systems running earlier versions of Windows. If the operating system was not updated, this property is still available but has no effect.
A value that specifies the deployment scenario of the server as it pertains to Extended Protection. Only available if extended protection is used.
This property is only available on the server and can only be used when with either or is used.

Supported by default on Windows 7 and above. May require an update on systems running earlier versions of Windows. If the operating system was not updated, this property is still available but has no effect.
A structure that sets the Server Principal Names (SPNs) the server is willing to accept as part of validating Extended Protection data. SPNs are validated when a is used without a or when is set.
This property is only available on the server and can only be used with .
If all of the above requirements are met, this property must be set for security verification to succeed. Otherwise, it must not be set.
Supported by default on Windows 7 and above. Requires update to the operating system on other platforms. If the operating system was not updated, this property is still available but has no effect.
